datafield.subfield: Analysis of suprathermal nuclear processes in the solar core plasma

A consistent model for the description of suprathermal processes in the solar core plasma naturally triggered by fast particles generated in exoergic nuclear reactions is formulated. This model, based on the formalism of in-flight reaction probability, operates with different methods of treating particle slow-down in the plasma, and allows for the influence of electron degeneracy and electron screening on processes in the matter. The model is applied to examine slowing-down of 8.7 MeV α-particles produced in the ${}^{7}\mathrm{Li}(p,\alpha )\alpha $ reaction of the pp chain, and to analyze suprathermal processes in the solar CNO cycle induced by them. Particular attention is paid to the suprathermal ${}^{14}{\rm{N}}{(\alpha ,{\rm{p}})}^{17}{\rm{O}}$ reaction unappreciated in standard solar model simulations. It is found that an appreciable non-standard $(\alpha ,p)$ nuclear flow due to this reaction appears in the matter and modifies running of the CNO cycle in ∼95% of the solar core region. In this region at $R\gt 0.1{R}_{\odot }$, normal branching of nuclear flow ${}^{14}{\rm{N}}\leftarrow {}^{17}{\rm{O}}\to {(}^{18}{\rm{F}})\to {}^{18}{\rm{O}}$ transforms to abnormal sequential flow ${}^{14}{\rm{N}}\to {}^{17}{\rm{O}}\to {(}^{18}{\rm{F}})\to {}^{18}{\rm{O}}$, altering some element abundances. In particular, nuclear network calculations reveal that in the outer core the abundances of (17)O and (18)O isotopes can increase by a factor of 20 as compared with standard estimates. A conjecture is made that other CNO suprathermal $(\alpha ,p)$ reactions may also affect abundances of CNO elements, including those generating solar neutrinos.
Skobeltsyn Institute of Nuclear Physics - Lomonosov Moscow State U. - Moscow 119991 - Russia

The first one is a standard binary-collision model with a Debye cut-off described by Sivukhin [, 26: #jpgaa5f30bib26]. We will refer to it as SIV66. In this model, the partial terms {({{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}/{\rm{d}}{t})}_{j} (j=e,i) in equation (, 9: #jpgaa5f30eqn9) are given by \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}}{{\rm{d}}{t}}\right)}_{j}=-\displaystyle \frac{4\pi {({Z}_{k}{Z}_{j})}^{2}{e}^{4}}{{(2{m}_{j}{T}_{j})}^{1/2}}{n}_{j}\mathrm{ln}{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{{kj}}\displaystyle \frac{{\rm{\Psi }}({x}_{j})}{{x}_{j}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 10 } \end{equation*} \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\rm{\Psi }}({x}_{j})=\mathrm{erf}({x}_{j})-\displaystyle \frac{2}{{\pi }^{1/2}}\left(1+\displaystyle \frac{{m}_{j}}{{m}_{k}}\right){x}_{j}\exp (-{x}_{j}^{2}),\end{eqnarray} \end{align*} \tag{ 11 } \end{equation*} \begin{equation*} \begin{align*}

The second model developed by Kamelander [, 27: #jpgaa5f30bib27] is based on the Fokker-Planck collision theory. We will refer to it as KAM86. This model makes it possible to carry out an extended analysis of particle slowing-down in a dense matter. It can operate with Maxwellian as well as Fermi-Dirac distribution functions, taking into account degeneracy of electron component. For the energy loss rate {({{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}/{\rm{d}}{t})}_{j} (j=e,i) one obtains [, 27: #jpgaa5f30bib27,, 28: #jpgaa5f30bib28] \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}}{{\rm{d}}{t}}\right)}_{j}=-\displaystyle \frac{8{\pi }^{2}{({Z}_{k}{Z}_{j})}^{2}{e}^{4}{(2{m}_{k})}^{1/2}}{{m}_{j}{E}_{k}^{1/2}}\mathrm{ln}\,{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{{kj}}\times {G}_{j}({v}_{k}),\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where the quantity Gj is a function of particle velocity vk. It is given by \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{G}_{j}({v}_{k})={J}_{j,2}\left[1-\displaystyle \frac{{m}_{j}}{3{E}_{k}}\displaystyle \frac{({J}_{j,4}+{J}_{j,1}{v}_{k}^{3})}{{J}_{j,2}}\right],\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} and {f}_{j}({v}_{j}) is the velocity distribution function of plasma species j. If all species are Maxwellian, the integrals {J}_{j,m} (m=1,2,4) are taken analytically and after some algebra equation (, 15: #jpgaa5f30eqn15) can be reduced to the form of equation (, 10: #jpgaa5f30eqn10) in which the function {\rm{\Psi }}({x}_{j}) is replaced by \widetilde{{\rm{\Psi }}}({x}_{j})

Under conditions typical of the solar core (\rho \sim 150 g cm-3 and T\sim 1.3 keV), the electron temperature Te is close to the Fermi energy {E}_{{\rm{F}}}=({{\hslash }}^{2}/2{m}_{e}){(3{\pi }^{2}{n}_{e})}^{2/3}. For example, in the inner core {T}_{e}/{E}_{{\rm{F}}}\sim 2.4 and the plasma electrons are in a weakly degenerate state. To incorporate electron degeneracy in our model, we properly determine the electron distribution function {f}_{e}({v}_{e}) which obeys Fermi-Dirac statistics, 6: #jpgaa5f30fn2

\end{equation*} In equation (, 21: #jpgaa5f30eqn21), the degeneracy parameter η (=\,\mu /{T}_{e} with μ being the chemical potential) is chosen to satisfy the normalization condition \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\int }_{0}^{\infty }{f}_{e}({v}_{e})4\pi {v}_{e}^{2}\,{{\rm{d}}{v}}_{e}={n}_{e}.\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} The Coulomb logarithm \mathrm{ln}\,{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{{kj}} is corrected to electron degeneracy by using an ad hoc procedure [, 29: #jpgaa5f30bib29,, 30: #jpgaa5f30bib30] of the replacement Te in equation (, 13: #jpgaa5f30eqn13) by {({T}_{e}^{2}+{T}_{{\rm{F}}}^{2})}^{1/2} where {T}_{{\rm{F}}} is the Fermi temperature. Substituting now the distribution function {f}_{e}({v}_{e}), equation (, 21: #jpgaa5f30eqn21), into equations (, 17: #jpgaa5f30eqn17)-(, 19: #jpgaa5f30eqn19), one can calculate the energy loss rate {({{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}/{\rm{d}}{t})}_{e}, equation (, 15: #jpgaa5f30eqn15), through k - e collisions with degenerate electrons

The third model for energy loss being considered was developed by Skupsky [, 31: #jpgaa5f30bib31]. We will refer to it as SKUP77. This model is based on a different energy loss mechanism. It was assumed that a charged particle k induces an electric field in a matter, which acts back on this particle and ultimately decreases its kinetic energy. For this mechanism, the energy loss rate is expressed as \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}}{{\rm{d}}{t}}\right)=-\displaystyle \frac{{Z}_{k}^{2}{e}^{2}}{2{\pi }^{2}}\int \displaystyle \frac{{\bf{k}}\cdot {{\bf{v}}}_{k}}{{k}^{2}}\displaystyle \frac{{\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Im}}}{{\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Re}}^{2}+{\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Im}}^{2}}\,{\rm{d}}{\bf{k}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where {\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Re}} and {\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Im}} are the real and imaginary part of the matter dielectric function \epsilon ({\bf{k}},{\bf{k}}\cdot {{\bf{v}}}_{k}), respectively. Using the random-phase-approximation form of the quantum-mechanical dielectric function, Skupsky [, 31: #jpgaa5f30bib31] obtained that the particle energy loss to plasma electrons of arbitrary degeneracy is given by \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}}{{\rm{d}}{t}}\right)}_{e}=-{E}_{k}{n}_{e}\displaystyle \frac{{Z}_{k}^{2}{e}^{4}}{{T}_{e}^{3/2}}\displaystyle \frac{{(2{m}_{e})}^{1/2}}{{m}_{k}}\displaystyle \frac{4}{3}\left[\displaystyle \frac{\pi }{{F}_{1/2}(\eta )}\,\displaystyle \frac{1}{{e}^{-\eta }+1}\right]\mathrm{ln}\,{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{\mathrm{RPA}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where {F}_{1/2}(\eta ) is the Fermi integral to order 1/2 \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{F}_{1/2}(\eta )={\int }_{0}^{\infty }\displaystyle \frac{{x}^{1/2}\,{\rm{d}}{x}}{{e}^{x-\eta }+1}.\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} The quantity \mathrm{ln}{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{\mathrm{RPA}} in equation (, 24: #jpgaa5f30eqn24) is a generalization of the classical Coulomb logarithm. It has the following form \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\mathrm{ln}\,{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{\mathrm{RPA}}=(1+{e}^{-\eta }){\int }_{0}^{\infty }\displaystyle \frac{{k}^{3}}{{({k}^{2}+{k}_{0}^{2})}^{2}}{\left[\exp \left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\hslash }}^{2}{k}^{2}}{8{m}_{e}{T}_{e}}-\eta \right)+1\right]}^{-1}{\rm{d}}{k},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where {k}_{0}^{2}={k}_{{\rm{D}}}^{2}{F}_{1/2}^{\prime }(\eta )/{F}_{1/2}(\eta ) and {k}_{{\rm{D}}}^{2}=4\pi {n}_{e}{e}^{2}/{T}_{e}. We should note that this formula somewhat differs from \mathrm{ln}{{\rm{\Lambda }}}_{\mathrm{RPA}} originally presented in [, 31: #jpgaa5f30bib31]. Equations (, 24: #jpgaa5f30eqn24) and (, 26: #jpgaa5f30eqn26) were derived for the case where the particle velocity vk is less than the average electron velocity \langle {v}_{e}\rangle. Also one needs to assume that {\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Im}}\lt {\epsilon }_{\mathrm{Re}}

[, 32: #jpgaa5f30bib32] recently proposed a reduced model for particle energy loss through scattering off plasma electrons. We will refer to it as EVRG13. The model conveniently interpolates between limiting cases for the loss rate {({{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}/{\rm{d}}{t})}_{e} based on classical and quantum kinetic equations. It gives \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{\left(\displaystyle \frac{{{\rm{d}}{E}}_{k}}{{\rm{d}}{t}}\right)}_{e}=-\displaystyle \frac{4\pi {Z}_{k}^{2}{e}^{4}}{{m}_{e}{v}_{k}}{n}_{e}\mathrm{ln}{\rm{\Lambda }}\times {\rm{\Psi }}({x}_{0}),\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where the function {\rm{\Psi }}({x}_{0}) is described by equation (, 11: #jpgaa5f30eqn11). The argument x0 is \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&{x}_{0}={\left(\displaystyle \frac{{m}_{e}}{{m}_{k}}\displaystyle \frac{{E}_{k}}{{T}_{e}}\right)}^{1/2}{\left[\displaystyle \frac{\sqrt{\pi }}{2{F}_{1/2}(\eta )(1+{e}^{-\eta })}\right]}^{1/3}.\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} The approximation formula for \mathrm{ln}\,{\rm{\Lambda }} has the following form \begin{equation*} \begin{align*} \begin{eqnarray}&&\mathrm{ln}\,{\rm{\Lambda }}=\displaystyle \frac{2{m}_{e}{v}_{e}^{2}}{{\hslash }{\omega }_{e}}\,\displaystyle \frac{0.321+0.259{x}_{0}^{2}+0.0707{x}_{0}^{4}+0.05{x}_{0}^{6}}{1+0.13{x}_{0}^{2}+0.05{x}_{0}^{4}},\end{eqnarray} \end{align*}

\end{equation*} where {\omega }_{e}=\sqrt{4\pi {n}_{e}{e}^{2}/{m}_{e}}. For the electron velocity ve in equation (, 29: #jpgaa5f30eqn29) we consider the most probable velocity {v}_{e}^{\prime } satisfying the equation {{\rm{d}}{f}}_{e}({v}_{e})/{{\rm{d}}{v}}_{e}=0. With the electron distribution function {f}_{e}({v}_{e}), equation (, 21: #jpgaa5f30eqn21), we found that in the solar core plasma {v}_{e}^{\prime }\simeq \sqrt{2{T}_{e}/{m}_{e}}
A discussion of the Borexino Physics Program can be found at :

Note that one more consequence of electron degeneracy is Pauli blocking—a restriction of scattering collision between an electron and other particle [, 33: #jpgaa5f30bib33]. However, it plays a subdominant role and is not considered here
